org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR IMMIGRATION SERVICE
REPORT OF HEARING IN THE CASE OF JOHN MATTHEWS
Under Department Warrant No. 54904/149, Dated November 15, 1920
Hearing conducted by Thos. M. Fisher, Immigrant Inspector, At McNeil Island Penitentiary, Wash. on January 11, 1921 Minutes taken and transcribed by C.V. Cattrell, Junior Clerk.
Said John Matthews being able to speak and understand the English language satisfactory, an interpreter; - -, contempt in - - was not employed ______

Said John Matthews was then informed that the purpose of said hearing was to afford him an opportunity to show cause why he should be be deported to the country whence he came, said warrant of arrest being read, and each and every allegation therein contained carefully explained to him, said person was then offered an opportunity to inspect the warrant of the arrest and the evidence upon which it was issued, which privilege was not accepted; and alien being first duly sworn - the following evidence was then and there presented:

Q At the hearing to be accorded you under this warrant of arrest you have the right to be represented by counsel. Is is your desire to be represented? A. No. Q What is your name? A. Jack Matthews Q How old are you? A.I am twenty-eight now. Q Where were you from? A. I was born in the Ukrainian, under the flag of Austria. Q When did you leave Australia? A. I left Austria in 1906 or 1907. Q Where did you go? A. I came to New York. Q Do you know what boat you came on? A. I landed at St. John or Halifaz; St. John I think. Q Where did you get on the boat? A. I got on the boat at Antwerp, Belgium. Q Do you know the name of the boat? Montezuma Q Do you know the date you arrived at Halifaz or St. John? A. No, sir. Q Do you know about what time? A. It was in the spring of the year, in April Q It was in 1906 or 1907? A. Yes Q Where were you going? A. I was going to New York; I stayed there for a short time while then I went back to Montreal. I was in Ottawa because I had a friend there I wanted to stay there. Q Who was your friend in Ottowa? A. He has gone back home before the war. Q Were you coming to him? A. When I found his address is there I wanted to find him. Q How long were you in Ottowa? A. Not very long; then I went to Cobolt (phonetic spelling) in Ontario, the big mining place. Q How long there? A. I was there for about 9 years, at Cobalt, Porcupine, and Golcondo in the mines. Q You were working in the mines? A. Yes sir. Q What were you doing in the mines? A. I was a machinist. Q You are a machinist are you? A. Yes, sir. Q After that where did you go? A. After that, I was there for quite a while then I went to Sault Ste Marie; I was working in the machine shop for the McPine people - - that is a big iron mine. Q Then after you left there where did you go? A. After I left there I went down to British Columbia, Vancouver, between Vancouvr and Prince Rupert, Canada, prospecting. Q Then where? A. I stayed there for a while then I came to the United States in 1919. Q What month? A. Between September, or about September. Q How did you come to Seattle? A. By boat. Q From Vancouver? A. From Prince Rupert Q Did the boat touch at Vancouver or Victoria? A. Yes. Q Were you examined by Immigrant Inspector and pay head tax? A. Yes I have my receipt here- -they have it here in the office. Q How long did you stay in Seattle? A. I went to Alaska, to the Kennicott Mine, Alaska. Q How long did you work there for them? A. I worked there two months before I was arrested.

Q You were charged with sending obscene matter through the mail? A. Yes Q You entered a plea of guilty? A. Yes Q That was in Valdez? A. Yes. My sentence was one year. Q It was one year and one day, wasn't it? A. I am not sure, yes. Q That was May 4, 1920, you were sentenced? A. Yes. Q Now you had been arrested on another charge? Weren't you arrested, something about a watch? A. Yes Q You pleaded not guilty to that? A. I pleaded not guilty and they didn't find me guilty. Q They acquitted you? A. Yes Q It was charged you took that watch? A. The charge against me was they found a watch in my possession on which had been lost from the United States post office, which I bought in Seattle before I took the boat. When I went to work I carried that watch with me. Q You were acquitted of the charge? A. Yes, I was not guilty. Q Have you ever taken the steps to become a citizen of the United States? A. No, no papers. Q Have any relations living in the United States or in Canada? A. Yes, I have a brother in Canada. Q What is his name? A. Mike Matthews. Q Where does he live? A. Alberta Q What place? A. I write every time to Winnipeg, Ukrainian Labor Temple Q What town? A. In Winnipeg Q Did you ever become a citizen of Canada? A. No, sir, I did not. Q Have you any property in Canada or in the United States? A. I have property in Canada, not in the United States. Q Where in Canada? A. In the "West Shining Tree", that is a mining claim in Ontario. Q Have you a title to it? A. Not here, no. Q Have you relatives in the old country? A. One sister in the old county. Q Do you know here address? A. I haven't heard since the war started. Q Now then, is there anything else you want to say to show why you should not be deported from this country? A. I got nothing to say. My record in Canada, which is as clear as could be must speak for me. Q Who knows about your residence in Canada? A. You could write to Cobolt and find my name. Q Who knows you? A. The people who know me there, write to the Beaver Mine. Q They know you under this name of Matthews? A. Yes. Write the O'Brien people, Golcondo. Q What is the address of your parents in the mine? A. I never heard since I have been arrested. One is an engineer and the other is a miner and they work different places; also I never wrote from here to let them know where I am now; I only wrote to my brother from here.
Head tax receipt, #14188 Form 569a dated Victoria, B.C. August 31, 1919, signed Edward Huestis;

also a School Tax Receipt, #13556, dated October 30, 1919, showing receipt from J. Matthews of five dollars for school. 24, signed by C.W. Lloyd, school tax collector for town or school district of Blackburn
